repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Agricultural Extension and Food
            Production Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcomes of the Agricultural
            Extension and Food Production Projects for Nepal were barely
            satisfactory for the agricultural extension program and
            unsatisfactory for the food production program. Both
            projects suffered a number of shortcomings, from design
            through implementation. The project period was set too short
            to implement complex institution-building projects and
            phasing of substantial construction programs was
            unrealistic. Little attention was paid to the availability
            of suitably qualified technical staff and lines of command
            were not clearly delineated. Administrative and budgetary
            problems were not properly identified, the availability of
            relevant technology was ill-assessed, and farmers did not
            participate in the identification and prioritizing of their
            perceived problems and needs. Several key lessons can be
            learned from these projects. First, during the initial years
            of an extension project, little more can be achieved than
            the establishment of an administrative framework. Second, a
            single line of command has to be maintained and management
            performance monitored in systems operation. Third, a
            bottom-up approach to extension and research is essential.
            Fourth, staff have to be provided with adequate incentives
            to ensure motivation and staff continuity. Lastly, staff
            recruitment procedures and training require adequate
            standards to ensure staff quality.

docna.cdata!:
Nepal - Hill Food Production Project :
            Credit 1101 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Hill Food Production
            Project : Credit 1101 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Hill Food Production Project aims to
            increase food production in four western Hill districts of
            Gorkha, Lamjung, Syanja, and Tanahu, by providing
            appropriate extension advice and support services for
            undertaking low-cost farming practices selected to have an
            immediate impact on food production, better animal health
            and increased availability of livestock feed. The project
            also includes provision of fertilizer for the project area.
            It is expected that the project will reach nearly 50% of the
            147,000 farm families in the project area. Irrigation works
            benefitting at least 10,000 farm families and trails and
            bridges benefitting all the population in these districts
            will also be upgraded. In view of the remoteness of the
            project area, there is a risk that all components may not be
            undertaken effectively and the interrelated services may not
            be provided; there is also the risk that area farmers may
            not have access to the development services. The project is
            therefore designed to minimize the administrative and
            logistical difficulties of providing services in remote
            areas through the use of local agricultural service centers.
            These centers have been found to be effective in other
            projects in marshalling and directing services and in
            reaching a broad spectrum of participants.
